timeline.message:
frontendscanner: Disable CSP so it always work

Relates to zaproxy/zaproxy#4893 .

Signed-off-by: Pamplemousse <xav.maso@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: Should a head be injected before the body start tag if one doesn't exist or would that break other things?
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText:
I don't think it would... I will give it a try.
As this code was already written (most of the content from FrontEndScannerProxyListener has been copy-pasted from ExtensionFrontEndScanner), and no issues were mentioning that, I did not touch it.
But more generally, it could be taking these two cases into consideration:

no <head> present;
empty <head>.
replies.author: Pamplemousse

timeline.message:
frontendscanner: Disable CSP so it always work

Relates to zaproxy/zaproxy#4893 .

frontendscanner: Deal with absent and empty `<head>`

frontendscanner: Deal with absent and empty `<head>`

Signed-off-by: Pamplemousse <xav.maso@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: It seems a little strange to pass the LOGGER. Is there any reason the listener shouldn't have it's own LOGGER constant?
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText:
I wasn't too sure what the output would look like, and I felt using the extension LOGGER would stay consistent with how it currently works.
I don't really have an opinion about it; Can definitely be changed if it's a smell.
Should the FrontEndScannerProxyListener have its own LOGGER then?
replies.author: Pamplemousse

replies.bodyText: Yes, otherwise the log statements are misleading (logged with one class name while they are in another).
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Aren't these only needed in the Extension?
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText:
Actually, no: The onHttpResponseReceive has a check using it.
On that note, I think I remember seeing a this.isEnabled() (in the ExtensionFrontEndScanner), but it's returned value was not always the same that the options.isEnabled().
What's the difference?
replies.author: Pamplemousse

replies.bodyText: An extension can be enabled/disabled by the user, which is different than that option.
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Should this bail if there is no host header (or HTTP 1.0/ HTTP 0.9)?
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText:
Dunno.
This code is refactored (copied) from the ExtensionFrontEndScanner, and I did not mean to solve / improve anything else than the issues I was focusing on.
replies.author: Pamplemousse

replies.bodyText: It would be better with getHostName() though.
replies.author: thc202

replies.bodyText:
It does not work (out-of-the-box):
I tried replacing String host = msg.getRequestHeader().getHeader("host"); with String host = msg.getRequestHeader().getHostName(); , but most tests failed in consequence.
When trying to investigate, it seemed that getHostName() was somewhat failing and shortcutting the rest of the onHttpReceiveMethod (raising an issue).
Sadly, I don't have time right now to dwelve more into that... Unless you have hints about this behavior, I will continue looking into that tomorrow.
replies.author: Pamplemousse

replies.bodyText: Pretty sure that because your messages don’t have an actual request object.
replies.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText: I’ll check it out this evening and let you know.
replies.author: kingthorin
kingthorin

timeline.author: kingthorin
kingthorin

timeline.bodyText: These are null host because there's no request object?
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText: It's null because the host header was not set. I updated the setUp so it's more explicit.
replies.author: Pamplemousse

timeline.bodyText: final
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText:
Should it be final in ExtensionFrontEndScanner.java too?
What about api here?
And what about api, and proxyListener in ExtensionFrontEndScanner.java?
replies.author: Pamplemousse

replies.bodyText:
The comment is for both lines.
In the extension they can't be as they are not being initialised in the constructor.
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: static

timeline.bodyText: numberOfChildren
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText:
head.getStartTag().getEnd()?
Could you add a test with <head> not at the start? e.g.:
<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">

<head>
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: static
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText:
It would be more clear with a parameterized test, all headers would be tested regardless of one failing and the one failing would be more obvious.
Could you move to before (or after) the tests that are checking the injections?
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Could you add a test with several meta tags?
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Could you add tests for when not enabled? (One for the CSP headers that should not be removed and another that the content remains the same.)
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: private
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Would be better to not turn off, this affects all tests.
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.message:
frontendscanner: Test when disabled in `options`

  * ensure html is not modified
  * ensure CSP headers are untouched
Signed-off-by: Pamplemousse <xav.maso@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: Could be removed, no longer used.
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Was the closing head at the end on purpose?
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: This one is now somewhat redundant with the other tests, now that all are using the head not at the start. Would be great to restore one of the previous tests that had just head to keep covering that part.
timeline.author: thc202
